dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Presumably Bremen: A church steeple in the foreground, th town square behind it. (Actual footage from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUSTAV VON WANGENHEIM, portraying the character of Hutter stands in front of a mirror tying his neckpiece. He wears early 19th-century German traveling clothes. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: GRETA SCHROEDER, portraying the character of El (Hutter's wife), leaning over a windowbox, dangling a pie string above a cat. She wears a 19th century hoop dress a her hair is in long finger-curls. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nice pussy. Nice pussy. You're very content right now, aren't you Ellen? You live in a nice house. You wear pretty clothing. And best of all, you're married to a wonderful man who's promised to love you forever. You little suspect that he's about to go on a long journey. And that, when he returns, he'll bring with him the death of love. And your womb will be (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU (O.S.) (cont'd) barren and your bed will be cold and in all the world you will be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same shot. The camera pulls back to reveal that the exter of Hutter's house is, in fact, a film set--a little oasis light--erected in a cavernous, barrel-vaulted studio. And standing in front of it are three men we'll come to k as MURNAU, GRAU, and MULLER. They're wearing lab coats an safety goggles and look more scientists than filmmakers. Everyone waits breathlessly for the director's approval..

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: And--end Print it! .-.and then flies into action with military precision: striking the set, switching off the phonograph (providing background music), carrying a chair to the director. Who rips off his goggles providing us with our first real at FRIEDRICH WILHELM MURNAU, 33: tall, handsome with red and a distant, preoccupied air he's capable of bringing t intense focus whenever he's concentrating. Which he demonstrates right now by focusing on...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Wolf, have we established pathos? «WOLFGANG MULLER, the photographer: 30s, glasses, a littl retiring. He looks up from where he's dismantling the cam clearly enrapt by MURNAU's attention.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Perfectly, Herr Doctor. In one take.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Good. Get the film to the lab right away. I want to see rushes first thing in the morning before we leave. Albin? ALBIN GRAU, producer and art director, walks over: late thirties, something of an Aesthete.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Yes, Herr Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up and strike your set, will you? This Potemkin village is costing our investors a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Shooting outside the studio will cost them even more.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Such is the price of genius. (shouting) God, save me from all this phony shit! He throws out his arms, accidentally sends a stack of fil tins flying from the hands of MULLER's assistant (PAUL). Everyone freezes. There's a long beat until, oblivious, MURNAU sits, turns to his script. The crew resumes its wo PAUL falls to his knees, scrambles to pick up the tins.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Herr Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Was there something wrong with the set, Friedrich?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: No, I'm anxious to get out of here, that's all. But I do need your inventory for the trip. Alsoa complete itinerary and a scene break-— down by costume and set. Speaking of which, I looked over your renderings last night for the last scene in Ellen's bedroom. I think they'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: High praise, Herr Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: We'll need blueprints, of course, and photos for when we finally get round to building it on Helgoland. And there was something else...oh yes, the cat was sluggish.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jesus, Albin. What's wrong with you? Take the damned thing out and have it shot. We look over to see HENRIK GALEEN, the screenwriter: 30s scholarly. He's sitting on packing crate, a sheaf of manu scripts spread across his lap.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Henrik, I hope we're not going to be out in the field without enough copies of your script.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: No, Friedrich. The brothers of the monastery are putting the gold leaf on them now.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (ignoring him, shouting) Hurry up, ladies and gentlemen! We have a train to catch! He turns back to his script, a steel door is opened, the and noise of 1921 Berlin pour in. Enter GRETA wearing a dressing gown and smoking a cigaret an ivory holder. Without her wig and make-up she seems dangerously young and beautiful, perhaps seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Nicely done, Greta. For a moment I even thought I saw a premonition of evil cross your face.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: (sitting beside him) It wouldn't surprise me. With all the spooky shit you've been saying to me. On-camera and off.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I told you, it's important for the realistic effect.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Yes, I know all about it. That's why we're being forced to pack up and go...what do you call this business again?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: "On-location..."

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: "On-location." To Transylvania.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, we're not going to Transylvania. We're going to Slovakia.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor, I believe one is supposed to call it Czechoslovakia now.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. Czechoslovakia.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: But why do we have to leave Berlin just now? At the start of the theater season?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (ignoring her) Albin, has your man arranged the cars?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Yes. Two.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea the parts I've been offered at long last? The salaries?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Will that be enough?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: It'll have to be. It's probably every car in the region.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor, you're ignoring me. (seductively) There was a time when you didn't ignore me...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Honestly, Greta, why would anyone care to act in a play when they had the opportunity to act in a film? As GRETA continues, a sordid-looking man in an ambulance driver's coat (a red cross on his sleeve) comes up and whispers something to MURNAU.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You certainly didn't think that when you were directing plays for Reinhardt. In any case, I don't like acting for the camera. A theatrical audience gives you life, while this thing... (indicating the camera) .-.-merely takes it from you. MURNAU turns sharply, takes her hand. Like MULLER before she responds rapturously.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (softly, confidently) Listen to me, Greta. I conceived this role especially for you. Ellen isa woman who discovers the ultimate expression of love in the most exquisite pain imaginable. Sound familiar? It will be your most demanding role. The role that will make you great as an actress. Consider it a sacrifice to your art. He stands, follows the sordid-lcooking man outside. She watches him, turns--a little embarrassed--to the others..

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: (recovering) I'm already being paid peanuts. ..-exits. GALEEN watches her go, turns to GRAU.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: So what'd you give the cat?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Chloral.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Chloral!

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: It's hard to keep the damn things docile under the lights. Did it show?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: It looked pickled.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Not so much as Greta.  MURNAU returns. Looks at his pocketwatch.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Almost dark. Well, everything here seems to be in hand...

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Friedrich, we still need to talk about the vampire.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: No, no...it's nearly dark. I'm already late. Wrap things up for me here, will you Albin? I'll see you all in the morning. MURNAU jogs to the door... ---exits.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: (shouting after him) But what costume should I pack for him? What make-up?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. And be sure that imbecile Gustav doesn't miss the train.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Where's he running off to?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Perhaps he has a woman.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (meaningfully) Or a man. They smile knowingly at this. Then, jokingly:

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Did you notice how concerned he was whether or not it was after dark?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Perhaps our director is the vampire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU climbs into his car, the chauffeur shuts the door, behind the wheel, drives away. We follow it through downt Berlin as the sun sets on sidewalks clotted with blind be and legless war veterans. As they come upon the crowded entrance of a chic cabaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «..the chauffeur turns to MURNAU...

dialogues.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: Front or back, Herr Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Back, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «».-and then steers into a dark alley where the car's hea lights illuminate a knot of pretty boys in army fatigues languidly congregating outside an unmarked door. MURNAU climbs out, raps on the door, is permitted inside. Then the door shuts behind him, his car drives off, and t illicit scene is plunged into darkness again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and smoky, echoing with Dixieland, populated by characters out of George Grosz: millionaires, whores, etc MURNAU passes through the crowd, climbs the stairs to an.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where--lying on a settee, watching the throng below--we discover a breathtaking young woman (MICHELINE): late tee pale skin, black hair, a very revealing flapper dress. MURNAU bares his teeth, jumps on her, buries his face in throat. She moans in pleasure, turns her face away, sucks smoke out of a cigarette holder.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor, I have a pain.  10. He lifts one of her legs, slowly peels back the dress and kisses the place where her rolled stocking reveals her th

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Does that feel better?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Are you really a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Yes. Of philosophy. She smiles lewdly at him, then suddenly scissors him betw her legs, flips him over onto the settee, climbs on top. Slaps him playfully. And then does it harder. MURNAU smil surrenders to her: now he's the one who's rapturous. We look down toward the stage: performing a torch song fo the corpse-faced Berliners is a large-busted woman in an evening gown. With bat's wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: De Stijl furniture, Die Briicke murals, etc. MURNAU is pa ing by candlelight when MICHELINE--half naked, smoking a cigarette in a holder--appears behind him. Weirdly, her entrance causes a few of the candles blow out.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Friedrich, do you have to go?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I'll be back in six or eight weeks.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: What shall I do without you?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Operate your cabaret. Dream of my return.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Won't you at least tell me what it is you're filming?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Not this time. It's a surprise...

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: I hate surprises.  11.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: «--a@ surprise for you. A film all about a woman like you... MURNAU stops what he's doing, takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: «--who sacrifices everything for her lover. MICHELINE grabs him by the throat...

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: And you think I would ever do such a thing? That's a rather skewed characterization coming from a man I've spent the past two hours raping like a woman. .«-.shoves him roughly away.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Still, I must admit you took it like a man.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You're the only one I've ever allowed to treat me that way.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: I don't doubt it... (pointedly) «..-Herr Doctor. Now tell me more about your movie.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: No. You'll see when it's finished. Now, have you eaten?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: I want to eat you.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You're not serious.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: But I am... She grabs him, pulls him into...  12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «-.throws him onto the bed, climbs on top of him.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Now kiss me good-bye, Friedrich. It's time that I was going.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Why won't you ever stay the night?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: I've told you: if I'm not back to count the night's receipts my staff will bleed me dry.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Stay. She stands, rests her shoe on his lower lip.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Beg.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Please stay. You love me, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Say it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Why not? I love you. She looks at him imperiously. Lightly slaps his face with toe of her shoe.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: That, Herr Doctor, is a very dangerous thing to say. Nevertheless, she kicks off her shoes, curls up beside hi He smiles contentedly, reaches up, turns out the light.  13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enter Hutter with flowers. He kisses his wife good-bye. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. MICHELINE, a long cape over her dress, emerges fro MURNAU's Bauhaus-style building. Hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: a record spinning silently on a phonograph. We pull back to see MURNAU asleep in his disheveled bed. wakes. Sees that he's alone. Knocks the arm off the recor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew of Nosferatu loads boxes onto one of the trains the watchful eye of GALEEN, GRAU, and MULLER. Suddenly there's a disturbance 0.S. and MURNAU--lapels pu up, hat pulled down--hurries up followed by porters and a of newspaper reporters. He grabs PAUL.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You work for me don't you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, Herr Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Then get my things. Albin? As PAUL begins directing the porters, MURNAU turns to GRA

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Tell them nothing. «then leaps onto the train. GRAU faces the reporters.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I am Albin Grau. Producer and art director of this picture.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: Where's Murnau?  14.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 3
dialogues.text: Is it true Murnau is filming Stoker's Dracula?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Friedrich Wilhelm Murnau is Germany's greatest filmmaker--in a class with such masters as Griffith and Eisenstein. At present he is supervising every detail of this unique on-location expedition. Exactly how unique you'll discover when the picture premieres in Berlin. And at that time, I'm certain you'll be convinced beyond the shadow of a doubt of the exceptional talent of this remarkable genius. The reporters clamor for more, GRAU climbs onto the train

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: You did that quite well, Albin.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: In the future I think there might actually be a living to be made from this sort of thing. Representative to the press. The last of the luggage is brought aboard, a whistle blow people make their farewells, the train pulls out of the..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+.roars out of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: MURNAU asleep. The door opens, MULLER peeks in. Sees MURNAU sleeping, closes it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MULLER moves down the corridor to the...  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where he finds the rest of the crew at lunch: GRAU, GALEE and PAUL (met earlier) and three young women: ELKE (cos- tumes), MARIA (script), and EVA (make-up). MULLER enters, sits. Tosses a rolled-up map to GRAU...

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Still asleep?

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Yes. Must have been quite a night.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Albin, let's see the map. .-.who clears off a place on the steamer trunk acting as table and unrolls a large map of Central/Eastern Europe.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: We'll cross the border into Czechoslovakia in a few hours at the foothills of the Carpathians and continue until the line ends at Oravska Magura. From there we'll go by automobile to a place near Poprad in the Vysoke Tatry: the High Tatra Mountains

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Apparently Herr Doctor's already filmed some of the exteriors there.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: He has?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: You didn't know?

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: That's odd. Anyway, you can assume we'll be filming all of Hutter's scenes there: the carriage scenes, the scenes at the inn with the superstitious natives...  Enter GUSTAV 16.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: «..the scenes between him and the vampire.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I still don't understand why we're not going to Tranyslvania.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Yes, everyone knows Count Dracula lives in Transylvania.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Strictly speaking, this isn't Dracula. The author's widow refused to sell us the rights to the novel. She's hoping to prepare a stage version to open in London.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Bound to make more money than any film.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Which is all very interesting, Henrik. But it doesn't address the larger question.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Which is?

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Who's playing our vampire? VON WANGENHEIM, the actor portraying Hutter.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: His name is Schreck.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Schreck?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Max Schreck. Apparently he was in the Reinhardt company. Did you know him, Albin?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Schreck? Are you sure you have the name right? "Schreck" is dialect for "shriek." What, did he specialize in fright roles?  17.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Just a character actor. Max Schreck.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Who told you he was playing the vampire?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor told me.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: I didn't know any Max Schreck in the Reinhardt company.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor told me he studied with Stanislavsky in Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: I'm surprised I've never heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: He's from the Russian school then?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Yes. As part of his preparation, he submerges his own personality in that of the character he's portraying. That's the reason he's not traveling with us. Herr Doctor told me went on to Czechoslovakia weeks ago--in order to absorb the flavor of the place, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: God, you don't think he's been sleeping in a coffin?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor also told me that, once we arrive and begin filming, Max will never appear to us except in full costume and make-up...

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: A rather extreme interpretation of Stanislavsky, if you ask me. Why wasn't I told about this?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: -.-and that furthermore we'll film him only at night.  18.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Why wasn't I told about that?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: (looking out the window) There are the Carpathians. Our first sunset in...what's the script say, Henrik?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: "The country of blocd-red mountains."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun sets behind the train as it races into the dense forests of Eastern Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. The corridor is packed with sleeping peasants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is nodding off except for GRAU who casts, on the steamer trunk, tarot cards: the fool, death, the ten of swords. Suddenly the door opens. Enter MURNAU.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I see we're knee-deep in peasants.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: When did you wake up?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (sitting) The Czech guard woke me at the border. What have you been doing?

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Actually we've been talking about you.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Your previously shot footage, your heretofore unannounced additions to the acting company...

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: As the producer of this film, Herr Doctor, I feel I have a responsibility (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU leans MURNAU looks 19. GRAU (cont'd) to ask if there's anything else you've neglected to tell us.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Why? What do the cards say?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Someone close to us will be going on a long journey. Now answer my question. forward conspiratorially.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Look, I confess: there are things I haven't told you about this production. But they'll all be revealed in the course of time.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: But how do you expect us to do our jobs when we're kept in the dark? at them, turns his intense focus on his crew-- especially GRAU. They hang on his every word. Suddenly the

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Exactly. Let me explain something to you. I intend ours to be the most realistic movie ever made. And what is realism? The unexpected. That's why I took all of you out of the studio and thrust you into the world. So that you'll be forced to react spontaneously to whatever you encounter there. And because of it, Nosferatu will not be just another filmed stage play. It will bea truthful record of reality. And that is what will make it great.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: But this is a fiction. A movie about a vampire. How can you talk about realism when the subject is so far removed from reality?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: My sense of style is realism. But my sense of art is moral. I want to explore evil with the eye of a scientist. train jolts to a stop.  20.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What's that? Why are we stopping? GRAU reaches over to the window, opens the blind, looks o Then he looks back at the others in awe.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: My god...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: the water reservoir being lowered onto the trai boiler (evidently this is why the train stopped). We pull back and up to see the passengers disgorging from the ste train (for a smoke, to stretch their legs, etc.) and then see what it is that inspired such awe in GRAU:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above: A vast, impenetrable forest lining the edges the railroad track like an enormous black curtain. On the ground: We follow MURNAU, GRAU, GALEEN, and MULLER they walk through the trees in silent wonder. Until:

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: The forest primeval. It grows thicker as we move east towards the Tatras.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: How do expect me to film in there?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: We could use an aeroplane.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: You're the pilot, Herr Doctor--at least you were in the last war. But I doubt even a low-flying Fokker could see into it.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: There's no place on earth like it. None of it's been thoroughly mapped. Whole armies have marched in never to be heard from again. And then there are the...animals--strange things which by all rights should be extinct. MURNAU, lost in thought, continues along by himself while catch up with...  21.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: and the rest the crew (ELKE, EVA, MARIA) walking along th the woods. EVA stops to pick up a pine cone, walks a litt distance by herself. And then stops. Her eyes opening wid in horror...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-her scream echoing through the trees before it's swall up again by the forest. Hearing it, the train crew grab lamps, hurry in her direc followed by some of the peasants and the rest of the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-film crew (except for MURNAU) who, following the lamps make their way through the thick tangle of undergrowth: GALEEN in the lead, MULLER taking up the rear. When suddenly the latter is caught up short when somethin grabs him by the throat. And yanks him into the darkness without a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few moments later, the search party emerges from the wo carrying EVA's body. They set it down near the tracks, be examining the body by lamplight while a few peasant women gather around, speak softly in Slovak. One of the things we hear them they say is..."nosferatu." Hearing it, GALEEN looks at the other members of the film crew. And that's when MURNAU emerges from the woods, hurr to the body, pushes everyone else away.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Get away from her. She's my responsibility. Somebody produces a sheet, MURNAU himself wraps her body then supervises the others as they load it onto the train like a ghost, through the steam. Then the whistle blows, the remaining people climb onboar  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow GRAU down the corridor--past the crew cabin (wh the dispirited crew take their seats), past peasants clut ching their rosaries and scribbling crosses everywhere--t door (without a cross). He knocks gently, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little light from the corridor reveals MULLER in bed.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Wolf, are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (dazed) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Wolf, I...sorry to wake you. Good night. And then door closes, taking with it the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train jerks to a stop waking the sleeping (under coat blankets) crew. They stir. PAUL opens the window shade. Beneath an overcast sky, a small procession passes carrie EVA's enshrouded body. Revealing behind them: MURNAU, standing beside a pair of touring cars. Paying off some k of police official.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gabled building at the foot of the looming Tatras. The place is deserted except for the pall bearers and the fil erew--the latter loading the cars with equal solemnity. GALEEN walks up to MURNAU as EVA is loaded onto a horse c

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: They'll put her on the next train back to Berlin. I've sent a telegram to her parents.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: What do we do now, Herr Doctor?  23. Beat. All eyes turn to MURNAU.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: We go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the last of the passengers disembark, PAUL stops at MULLER's door. Knocks.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Herr Muller? No answer. He knocks again.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Herr Muller? The door opens slowly as if by itself. And we see MULLER, bundled to the gills, sitting at the window: gaunt, dark rings under his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the crew prepares to depart, a little boy hands MURNAU wooden cage. MURNAU gives him a coin, the boy runs away.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: What's that? MURNAU holds up the cage: rats.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Rats? There aren't any rats called for in the script until the ghost ship: the vampire's disembarkation at Bremen.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: They're for mood, Henrik. At the castle. The train whistle blows and it pulls out of the station. Revealing MULLER standing, nonplussed, on the opposite si

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Wolf! MULLER turns, walks slowly towards them.  24.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Wolf, what's the matter with you? MULLER climbs silently into one of the cars followed by MURNAU, GALEEN, and PAUL. The others climb into the other one, drive up alongside.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: You take the rats! He throws the cage into MURNAU's car which takes the lead the cars disappear into the forest, we remain behind for a moment with the cart with the corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cars follow the heavily shaded road into the mountain

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Think there's anything to eat? GUSTAV roots around in the boxes in the back. He opens on packed with straw. Digs out a bottle filled with blood.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What in hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: My god, it's blood. It must be part of the make-up.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Don't you think you can carry realism too far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the sun sets over the mountains behind them, the cars emerge from the forest and stop in front of a large stone cottage with an attached stable. A large white cross has whitewashed on the thatched roof of the building. They begin unloading equipment, the INNKEEPER marches out

dialogues.speaker: INNKEEPER
dialogues.text: Good evening, Herr Doctor! «--and directs them inside.  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long wooden tables, a large hearth providing the only lig Seeing the crew, a couple of old women at their beads interrupt their prayers, begin setting out crockery, etc.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (to the Innkeeper) I wonder if I might be shown to my room.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: You're not eating, Wolf? But he ignores him, follows the INNKEEPER upstairs. MURNA sits at one of the tables, examines his script. The other sit with him, begin eating.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Does he seem ill to you?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: He's just tired. (to Murnau) What's on the schedule for tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Exterior shots of the inn. The arrival of Hutter in the carriage. Some shots in here.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Where are the extras?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (indicating the old woman) You're looking at them.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: These people can't act.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: They don't need to act. They're playing themselves.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Speaking of actors, I expected to meet Schreck here.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You'll meet Max when his time comes in the shooting schedule.  26. A little woman with a candle enters the main room and the leads them, one at a time, up a narrow, angular staircase

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the top of the staircase is a little hall with doors leading to the bedrooms.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Sleep well everyone. The call is for dawn. They all wish MURNAU a respectful good-night. Then he goe into his room, shuts the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bed, a little table with a candle. Illuminating walls festooned with crosses--some real, some painted. He shive and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -.-from outside: we watch him put out the candle. From 0. we hear squealing, and see...

dialogues.speaker: THE RATS
dialogues.text: squirming in the cage in the back seat of one of the cars The door closes, the engine turns over, and...

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE CARS
dialogues.text: pulls away from the inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow it as it drives through the dark forest. The ti dirge begins, grows louder as the sequence progresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car emerges in a moon washed clearing high in the mountains. It stops, the driver climbs out. Takes somethi from the back seat. Plunges back into the trees.  27. We follow him until he comes to a gaping, vine-clogged ca He hesitates for a moment, goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cave turns out to be a series of Christian catacombs. follow the figure past the primitive symbols cut into its black walls until he stops in front of a dark niche. Then he gingerly sets down the cage containing the rats, hurries back out. As the music grows very loud...

dialogues.speaker: A PAIR OF HANDS
dialogues.text: appears: marble white with fu manchu nails. They wrap lik spiders around the cage. Withdraw with it into the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scaffold has been erected leading to GUSTAV's second fl window. On top of it sits the camera/tripod operated by MULLER and PAUL--both wearing goggles and lab coats. 0O.S phonograph spins background music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rises. Hutter, in bed, wakes. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All right, Hutter. It's been a fitful night. You dreamed that a jackal frightened away the horses and left you stranded hundreds of miles from your beloved wife. But you're a modern man. Aman of science. You wake refreshed, eager to continue your journey to the castle of the nobleman who may very well make your fortune.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: in goggles and lab coat, is standing at the door to GUSTA room. Beside him stands GALEEN, at his feet sits ELKE.  28.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What's that beside your bed? Pick it up. It's that ridiculous book from the night before. The book about vampires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUSTAV in bed, MULLER at the window, GRAU out of sight of camera, MURNAU at the door. Since the last time we saw th room, all the crosses have been stripped from its walls.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Now you remember. The superstitious peasants put it there. The ones who warned you not to visit Orlock's castle, who warned you not even to speak his name--nosferatu, the unclean, the undead--lest you evoke the creature itself. The INNKEEPER'S WIFE peeks in from the hall behind MURNAU

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: What I'd like to know is: do all the rooms contain this book? Sort of the Transylvanian version of the Gideon's Bible?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: And--end. Henrik, please don't spoil the mood. Wolf, did you get that?

dialogues.speaker: INNKEEPER'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (ignoring her) Wolf...

dialogues.speaker: INNKEEPER'S WIFE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Herr Doctor, but...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Albin, deal with the natives... GRAU takes the INNKEEPER'S WIFE out into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Wolf!  29.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (distracted, quietly) The shot was perfect, Friedrich.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: What's gotten into you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Herr Muller slept poorly again last night.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Your name is Paul, isn't it? Please pack one of the cars as I instructed. You and you... (indicating Maria and Elke) «-ehelp him. Then you can all take the rest of the afternoon off. Not you, Gustav. Take an hour for lunch and then get into your traveling costume. Albin, is the carriage ready? Albin? He looks around angrily, charges into the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where GALEEN, GRAU, and the INNKEEPER'S WIFE are talking. GRAU, smoking a cigarette, seems especially annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What the hell has gotten into every- one?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: She's worried about the crosses.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Why am I being bothered with this?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: (to the Innkeeper's Wife) We'll put them back. They just over- whelm the composition.

dialogues.speaker: INNKEEPER'S WIFE
dialogues.text: I told you, Herr Grau, they are not for decoration. You should be more concerned about such things. And you should be more cautious than to leave here at night.  30.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: INNKEEPER'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Every night someone takes one of your... She mimes turning a steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Do you know anything about this, Albin?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: No. Where would anyone go?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Henrik, check the petrol. GALEEN hurries out. MURNAU pokes his head back into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew is packing up equipment, replacing the crosses,

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Has anyone been driving the cars at night? Everyone says no.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Wolf? Wolf? MULLER, staring blankly toward the mountains, turns angri

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: What do you want from me, Friedrich? I haven't taken your fucking car. MURNAU looks at him hard. Exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GALEEN is inspecting the cars. MURNAU emerges from the in

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Well, the tanks are definitely lower than when we arrived.  31.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Do you think the locals might be going for a joyride? GALEEN shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Well, do you think this will be a problem? GRAU steps out of the stable leading a pair of horses harnessed to a small carriage.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Only you can answer that, Herr Doctor. When will we meet our vampire?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Soon..

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUNSET
dialogues.text: As the sun sets over the forest... (Actual footage from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .«.-GUSTAV (as Hutter) walks along the side of a hill, pa an icon mounted in a little wooden shrine. (Recreated from Nosferatu.) We pull back to reveal MURNAU, GRAU, and GALEEN standing beside the car while MULLER films the scene.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: All right, Hutter. This is the icon the locals have erected to mark the boundary between the land of the living and the land of the dead. Look at it...and walk on. He does, walks out of the frame.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: And--end!

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Thank god, I'm starving.  32.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: There's food in the car. We're not going back just yet. As GUSTAV breaks out a wicker picnic basket...

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Where're we going, Friedrich?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: It's nearly dark. I can't do a night shoot. Not alone.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I had your equipment packed for you, Wolf. Albin will assist you. It's important that very few of us are present for this.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: I suppose we're reaching for the spontaneous effect you spoke of on the train. MULLER packs up his equipment, the others--still eating-- climbing into the car.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Incidentally, I hope everyone has their papers. Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Just in case of what?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: We're crossing the border. He climbs in. GALEEN and GRAU trade tired looks. Then we follow the car as it drives east, away from the setting s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind: the automobile pulls to a stop. Car doors sl O.S. We look up to see, illuminated by the headlights:  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: formerly a Medieval monastery, crumbling to ruins on the hilltop. MURNAU climbs up to its huge wooden door, opens

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Are we expected?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: So this is Poland. When did we cross the border?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: I was asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Quickly, don't lose this. This sense of dread. Now listen closely, Hutter... MURNAU returns, puts an arm across GUSTAV's shoulders, le him inside. The others follow, slowly, in the car...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: «after having been deserted on the road, a mysterious carriage found you and brought you here. You're tired, disoriented, and at last the fore- boding that infects the entire region has begun to infect you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+.through a courtyard faced with half-timbered walls.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Park over there, Albin. Wolf, hurry, set up the camera in there. MULLER climbs out, sets up the camera, while GRAU hooks u carbon-are lamp to a generator and floods the scene with light. Revealing, at the other end, a low archway, braced with a scaffold, leading into a black, forbidding tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: (indicating the scaffold) Who built this? I thought I was in charge of set construction.  34.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I sent workers ahead this morning. Never mind that now. Hutter, stand over there, out of sight and don't look until I call you. Wolf, get a second camera focused on Gustav--I want his reaction to this.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: To what? Infected by his enthusiasm, the men quickly set up the eq ment, climb into their lab coats and goggles. Then GRAU a GALEEN step behind the lights, MURNAU and MULLER each tak camera. There's a long moment heavy with anticipation...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Ready? All right, Wolf. Roll camera. «+»MULLER and MURNAU begin cranking their cameras...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (hypnotically) This is perfect. Just a dark hole. That's been untouched, unexplored for a long, long time. And then, one night, something crawls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-.and something emerges from the shadows. It's MAX SCHRE in the role of Count Orlock, the vampire. Cadaver-like in long coat and turban, he has a rodent face, talon-like na and he moves stiffly, as if hampered in his walking. MURNAU ET AL. watch him in frightened disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same, except recreated from Nosferatu.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (continued) Hutter! Meet Count Orlock!  35.

dialogues.speaker: HUTTER
dialogues.text: enters, sees Orlock. He freezes, stares in horror. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlock indicates the tunnel. Hutter, unnerved, follows. J as they're about to be engulfed by the darkness, Hutter l back at us with an expression of genuine terror.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (continued) And--end. GUSTAV, unnerved, rushes back while SCHRECK, unnoticed by others, disappears back into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: What the fuck was that!?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: That was your finest moment, Gustav.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: That wasn't acting! It was a trick, a cheap trick to...to...elicit a real response from me. It was unfair, it was unethical, and it was...it was...

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: .-.genius.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Yes. Well done, Gustav.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Gustav. GUSTAV looks at them in disbelief and then, off their awe reaction:

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: (preening) It was good, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: All right, Gustav, if you're quite finished collecting your laurels. Let's pack up.  36.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: That's it? Why drive all this way and shoot one scene?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I would have driven anywhere at any- time to get that look of Gustav's. Albin, I think we should take the film with us. GRAU collects the film, exits to the car.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: We'll leave the equipment, come back tomorrow, shoot the exteriors of the castle and some of the scenes with Hutter alone. Max will join us after dark and we'll shoot their scenes together. Wolf? Where's he gotten to now?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Never mind him. What's happened to Schreck?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Yes, Friedrich, where is Schreck? And why won't he join us until night? Where does he sleep?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: The earth in which he was interred, no doubt.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: That's enough of that, Gustav. Now listen to me, both of you: for the remainder of the shoot, Max will be Count Orlock. He will not break character, he will not answer questions as Max Schreck.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Will he answer questions as the vampire?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Just leave him alone, Henrik. The man will be absolutely authentic, without any phony effects. He'll be the vampire, we'll film it, and that'll be that.  37.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Sounds like a lunatic to me.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: No, I've heard about these Russian-— trained actors. Still, if the son of a bitch tries to suck my blood in the name of verisimilitude...

dialogues.speaker: GRAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (calling) Friedrich! They hurry out of the courtyard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...discover GRAU crouched over a prone MULLER.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: I found him here. He's...fainted.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Henrik, get the car. Gustav, help us lift him up. While GALEEN fetches the car, the others help MULLER to h feet. Then the car arrives, GALEEN climbs out, helps him side. And that's when they see the two bleeding pinholes MULLER's throat. GALEEN looks at them, glares angrily at.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: who turns away, shuts the castle doors, looks up to see:

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: watching them from a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU returns to the car, climbs in, they drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAU tends to MULLER's wounds while GALEEN stares daggers MURNAU. There's an uncomfortable silence.  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up, GRAU helps MULLER inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -.-where the racket wakes the INNKEEPER'S WIFE who climbs the stairs carrying a candle.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Brandy, hurry. She shuffles out as MULLER slumps down at one of the tabl

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: All right, Herr Doctor, what's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Stop being so theatrical, Henrik. You'll wake everyone in the house. She returns, sets a bottle of brandy in front of MULLER. looks up at her--exhausted, deathly pale--and that's when too, sees the wounds. Crosses herself...

dialogues.speaker: INNKEEPER'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Nosferatu... .-.and stumbles out again.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: This is too much!

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Answer me, Herr Doctor. Is this some...stunt to evoke terror in us?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I had nothing to do with this. Enter PAUL.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What's happened?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: He's ill.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Put him to bed.  39. PAUL leads him away, the men help themselves to the brand

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: What about the marks on his throat?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I don't know, Gustav. They're mosquitoes, bloodsucking insects.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Oh for chrissakes, Friedrich, don't quote my script back at me.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: All right, what do you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: You heard the woman--nosferatu.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Henrik, that's the kind of thing I'd expect from Albin, not you.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Look, I concede it may not be a monster who casts no reflection in a mirror, but why couldn't it be some deranged person who haunts these woods and has succeeded in scaring these people to death.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: We've driven thirty kilometers to- night. How exactly did this deranged person follow us?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Well...what about Schreck?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Yes, what about him?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You're not agreeing with... (indicating Gustav) «-ehim now, are you? Max Schreck's a character actor from Berlin. I admit his preparation is odd...

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Odd enough to get so deep inside his vampire character that he forgets Max Schreck altogether?  40.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: God knows I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Schreck's peculiarities are like lovemaking games: you believe them while they're happening but you always stop before anyone is seriously hurt.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: You would know...

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, I intend to put all of those crosses back up in my room. GUSTAV goes off to bed followed by GRAU and GALEEN. MURNA remains at the table staring into the candlelight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind: a figure (SCHRECK, but we don't see his face sits at a table reading by candlelight. On the floor arou him are mountains of old, rotting books. O.S. we hear a car drive up, a door closing. Footsteps. T figure closes his book with white, tapering fingers.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: (breathing with difficulty) The woods decay, the woods decay and fall, The vapors weep their burthen to the ground. Another figure (we can't see who it is) enters and nervou sets a bottle of blood on the table.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Dinner? You set a very mean table. SCHRECK picks up the bottle...

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: No rats? ..-.and begins clicking his fingernails against it.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: There was a time when I was fed from golden chalices, but now....don't look at me that way. I've told you: in my old age I feed erratically...  41. The first figure leaves.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: «--often enormously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunset. GRAU and GALEEN examine papers spread across the of one of the cars.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: How much more, Albin?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: (locking at the schedule) Well, we're already finished at the inn and they're wrapping up the Czech exteriors today. If the scenes inside the castle go as smoothly, I don't see any reason why we shouldn't be filming in Wismar in a fortnight and onto Helgoland a fortnight after that. Ever been there? Helgoland?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: A cold little dune in the North Sea.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: I was just wondering how much longer Wolf will be able to hold up.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: He seems better. Herr Doctor's kept me away from him, but he remembers nothing from the night of his attack. As he says it, the second car lurches up. The other men c out.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (weak, but enthusiastic) Good. I got a pretty stunning sunset just now: rays shooting out behind clouds, real High Baroque stuff.  42.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: And where's... He bares his teeth, curls his fingers into claws.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: He'll be here by nightfall. They gather up their equipment, head into the castle.

dialogues.speaker: CLOCK
dialogues.text: with a skeleton on it. It strikes midnight. (Actual footage from Nosferatu. )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELKE and MARIA are finishing the set--hanging tapestries, setting the table, etc.--when the men enter and begin fix the lights (hooked up to humming generators), drawing the camera lines on the floor, etc.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (flipping through his script) We'll do two scenes here tonight: the first where Hutter dines with the vampire and the second where the vampire sees the picture of Hutter's wife. We'll shoot them in reverse order so Gustav can build emotionally to the more dramatic of the two. Albin, clear off the food and get the locket and the contract. Wolf, can we get it darker in here? Dustier? As everyone jumps to his commands, we pull back until we' watching the little area of light and activity through a gaping hole in the castle's roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: one of the automobiles. Suddenly, a claw-like h rakes across its chrome...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ---and a car horn blows 0.S.: startling the crew, turning eyes to MURNAU...  43.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Someone want to go scare up our vampire?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I'll get him. -.--who dashes out in one direction. As SCHRECK creeps in the other (accompanied, oddly, by a barely perceptible di of the arc lights). The crew freezes, watches him. In tur he watches them--especially the women. MURNAU hurries back in.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (breathless, relieved) Ah, there you are. For those of you who haven't met him, this is Max Schreck who will be portraying our vampire, Count Orlock. As you've no doubt heard, Max's method is a bit unconventional. I expect you all to respect his artistry in this matter. All right places everybody. Orlock, you sit there. SCHRECK sits at the end of the table, leers at the under- standably uncomfortable women. MURNAU walks over to GUSTA

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Gustav, do you have the locket?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Yes, Herr Doctor. As MURNAU continues, MARIA rolls a make-up cart over to SCHRECK, takes off his turban. Then she puts on a medical magnifier, picks up a stick of greasepaint. Stops. Trans- fixed. SCHRECK, on the other hand, is utterly intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: All right, Hutter. In this scene, Orlock is about to sign the real estate papers you've brought him... SCHRECK looks at the papers on the table in front of him. MARIA puts down the greasepaint...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: «--and you're about to make a con- siderable amount of money. When all of a sudden...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «--and picks up a powder puff. SCHRECK sneers at it.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: No, no make-up! What are you doing!?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Herr Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Albin, get these people off the set. GRAU directs ELKE and MARIA off the set. MURNAU gets down his haunches in front of GUSTAV and SCHRECK.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Gustav, you stand behind him, at his shoulder... GUSTAV stands behind SCHRECK, reading over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: «--Orlock, you read the document.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: It's blank.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Act it, for heaven's sake.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: What should it say?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: It's a contract... SCHRECK looks meaningfully at MURNAU.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: «e-a real estate contract.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I'd like some make-up.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Well you don't get any. Is everybody ready... MURNAU gets behind the camera, adjusts his goggles. Signa ELKE to put on the phonograph. And...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: «eeand, roll camera. Action. All right, Orlock, read the papers. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU (CONT.) (cont'd) Intensely. After all, how often do you get correspondence from the living? Hearing this, SCHRECK looks up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: No, don't look up. Don't look at the camera. You don't even care about the contents of the contract. All you can think about is all those juicy throats waiting for you in Germany. And you, Hutter. Even though it repels you, get closer to him. You want to point out a few details of the contract. But what's this? Drop the locket, Hutter. Hutter drops his locket onto the table. SCHRECK sees it, picks it up in his talons, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKET
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: a portrait of GRETA as Ellen Hutter inside. (Recreated from Nosferatu.) SCHRECK (0.S. This is Greta Schroeder. The actress. I've seen her photograph before.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, Orlock, you don't know her.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: He's suppose to ask who it is. Comment on her beautiful throat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She's frightening.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: What's he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: End!  46.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Jesus, Max...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: No, that's fine. Really. Henrik, help me here. Help the vampire find his motivation. GALEEN walks up to SCHRECK, kneels beside him.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: All right, Count. Think about it this way: what is the thing that inspires the most longing in you? The thing that is most desirable, and yet most unattainable? SCHRECK turns away, entranced by the thought. And then, a a long moment, turns back again.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: The light of the sun. Beat. GALEEN looks at him, not unaffected. Then MURNAU wa over, directs GALEEN out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Good, that's the emotion. Use it. Now when you see the locket ask who it is, Hutter will say it's his wife, you'll comment on her throat, and he'll take it back. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: What does it matter what I say? It's a silent picture.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Thank you, Orlock, for pointing out the technical deficiencies of our young art form. Talk to him, Henrik. You two seem to be getting along today.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: You have to understand, Count, if art does anything at all, it creates the skills necessary for appreciating it. Consequently silent pictures have created an audience of lip readers.  47.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: All right. Hutter collect your locket. Nosferatu read your papers. Wolf, roll camera--action!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutter stands behind Orlock who reads his papers. Hutter drops his locket, Orlock slowly scoops it up. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Who is this woman?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: It's my wife, Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: She has a beautiful bosom.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just go on. Snatch it back, Gustav. He does.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (continued) Okay, sign the papers, vampire. Orlock picks up a quill pen, signs.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I understand we're going to be neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How does that make you feel, Hutter? Hutter looks sick.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: And--end. Very good, give the lip readers a thrill. Wolf?  48.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: Got it in two.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Excellent! Next shot. Same set, a day earlier. Albin? MURNAU walks over to GRAU, the crew resets the scene. We remain behind with...

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: May I see the locket again, please? GUSTAV hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: You never met Greta in Berlin? Maybe you know her husband--her latest husband, I should say. Paul Wegener? The film director? SCHRECK just leers at it.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Don't slobber on it, for chrissakes. He walks away in disgust. MARIA and ELKE finish setting t table in front of him, MURNAU marches over, inspects it, a quick adjustment.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Let's go on. He goes over to the camera, adjusts his goggles. GUSTAV s down opposite SCHRECK who continues to ogle the locket.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Max, put the locket away. No Max, give it to... He indicates ELKE. SCHRECK gives it up reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: All right. Gustav, this is the scene from the night before, where you first meet the Count and he gives you dinner. Is that clear? Good, start eating. And you, Orlock--ignore your guest and read the papers he brought (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU (CONT.) (cont'd) you. Good. Excellent. Music. Roll camera. And--action!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutter eats uneasily while Orlock pores over a document. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (continued) Look at your host, Hutter. Could this have been the stranger who drove you to the castle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlock, his face concealed by a heavy wrap, sits in the driver's seat on top of the carriage. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Orlock examining the document. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (continued) Are you afraid of him? Is he even human? How do you feel about eating near him? About spending the night with him alone?

dialogues.speaker: HUTTER
dialogues.text: eats distractedly. (Recreated from Nosferatu.) MURNAU (0.S. (continued) Now reach for the knife. Cut a slice of bread. Slice...slice...watch your finger, Hutter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutter, his attention fixed on Orlock, cuts his thumb. A little blood wells up.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Damn!

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (getting carried away) Look, Nosferatu! Blood, BLOOD!!

dialogues.speaker: ORLOCK AND HUTTER
dialogues.text: Orlock looks up, drops the contract, stands quickly. He begins breathing very hard, tries to grab Hutter's hand. Hutter pulls away. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor!

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Damn it, Murnau, I really cut myself!

dialogues.speaker: GRAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Calm down, Gustav!

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: You did that intentionally! That knife was sharpened like a razor!

dialogues.speaker: ORLOCK AND HUTTER
dialogues.text: No longer recreated. SCHRECK grabs GUSTAV's hand again.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Get this asshole off of me! GALEEN and GRAU are rushing to help him when the light an camera tip over and the room goes dark. MURNAU locates another light, hooks it up. And that's when he sees SCHRECK--on his hands and knees, crouched over a prone MULLER. MURNAU shoves him away, replaces the light.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: My God, Wolf!  51. He rushes to MULLER's side, kneels down. Behind him, the upended camera spools film onto the ground.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: (To Schreck) What in hell is the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: He's a red Stanislavsky lunatic is what's the matter with him.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Wolf! Damnnit, Friedrich, he isn't breathing! MURNAU hurries over to him.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Gustav, get the women into the car. You... (indicating Paul) --.get the film. No one moves. Everyone is looking at SCHRECK.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I said get the film, take it to the car! He shoves PAUL, grabs GUSTAV by the arm...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Gustav, move! «-.-but GUSTAV just stands where he is and stares.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Leave the rest. Albin, help him with the film. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Albin! Nothing. MURNAU stands speechless, his worst nightmare realized: he's lost control of his film. The film finishes rolling out of the open camera. When it stops, MULLER is dead. That's when GALEEN looks at GRAU, takes the initiative.  52.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: (To Schreck) Help me with Wolf. Schreck, help me. SCHRECK does nothing. GRAU pushes past him, goes to GALEE Together they lift WOLF's body and start to carry it out.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: We're finished for the night. Every- one into the automobiles. ELKE, MARIA, GUSTAV, and PAUL hurry out. MURNAU glares at them, stands his ground by the broken camera.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Let's go, Herr Doctor. Leave the damn camera.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Schreck, you come too.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: No, he stays. MURNAU saves his most damning look for SCHRECK. 0.S. we h the sound of car doors slamming.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: All right, leave him. Let's go. MURNAU follows angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They load MULLER's body into one of the cars, disconnect cables. The castle goes dark, the cars drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The set is trashed, dimly lit by the carbon arc inside a projector (hooked up to a still-operating generator). SCH ambles through, glances at the phonograph, sniffs at some up. Accidentally turns on the projector. Then he watches the film--exterior shots of the Carpathia sunset--while we watch:  53.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK'S FACE
dialogues.text: He watches the celluloid sunset with an un-human astonish As if he hadn't seen the sun in centuries. Because he's really a vampire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU drives, GUSTAV sits beside him. MULLER and GALEEN in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: I suppose we'll have to drive all the way to Prague to find a decent hospital.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: He doesn't need a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cars pull up, people rush inside, help with the body, MURNAU buttonholes GRAU, pulls him aside.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (confidentially) Albin, tell me honestly. Do you think what's his name, Wolf's assistant, can finish filming this?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Paul? No chance.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: No. You're the closest we have to a photographer.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: (hearing them) What are you talking about? This film ends here.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: He told me he wanted us to go on.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Who?  54.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Wolf. He had a premonition. He said that if anything happened to him, we were to finish the movie.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: And that makes it all right? We're not going to have time to make a picture. We're going to spend the rest of our time here dealing with the local authorities...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I think we can bribe our way out of that.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: «--we have to bring his body back to Germany.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: We can ship it. Like what's-her-name, the girl on the train.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: She wasn't once your lover, you bastard! He takes a swing at MURNAU. MURNAU ducks out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Henrik. The film can't survive a long interruption. The financiers would take control and finish it themselves. And even if they didn't, it would ruin the spirit I've worked so hard to instill. We would need to begin again with entirely new personnel.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Are you even listening to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Actually, this may be propitious. Death can be used. Gustav's never been more on edge.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: You're out of your goddamn mind, you obsessive fucking fanatic!  55. GALEEN lunges for MURNAU, but MURNAU pushes him away. GAL the wind knocked out of him, falls on all fours.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I'll drive to the station tonight...no, I'll drive directly to Berlin. Get another photographer and be back within a week. The rest of you will wait here. MURNAU goes to GRAU, grabs him by the shoulders...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (intensely) You're the producer, Albin. Keep my company together. And as for you, Henrik... --.-then he climbs into one of the cars...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: .-.try to understand. When you wrote the scenario you had demons of your own to work out. And now I have mine. «and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, a figure reads by candlelight. And, once agai we hear footsteps 0.S. and a second figure enters.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: The woods decay, the woods decay and fall, The vapors weep their burthen to the ground, Man comes and tills the field and lies beneath, And after many a summer dies the swan.

dialogues.speaker: FIGURE, (MURNAU)
dialogues.text: How could you be so stupid?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Me only cruel immortality consumes; I wither slowly in thine arms, Here at the quiet limit of the world--

dialogues.speaker: FIGURE, (MURNAU)
dialogues.text: Stop reciting that damned poem!  56. The seated figure sits forward and we get our first real at MAX SCHRECK: eyes bloodshot, teeth yellow, skin tissue thin over a skein of black veins. This isn't movie make-u

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Did you think you could appease me with rats, Herr Doctor? At that the figure slams his hands onto the table: it is, indeed, MURNAU.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You killed my photographer, you fool!

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Alas for this gray shadow once a man. Or even bottles of blood?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Stop acting so pleased with yourself!

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Did I kill one of your people, Murnau? I can't remember...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: We had an arrangement!

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Don't pretend you mourn for the man, Herr Doctor. I know you...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You monster, why him? Don't you understand the film can't go on without him? There are others less indispensable. Why not the script— girl? Why not...

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Ah. Perhaps I'll eat the scriptgirl later.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Our bargain. You agreed not to hurt my people. SCHRECK grabs MURNAU's arm. For an instant we see just ho afraid he really is of SCHRECK...

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I think you forget our bargain.  57. «and then he yanks his arm away, puts some distance betwe himself and the vampire. No answer. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Listen to me. I have to go to Berlin to get another photographer. You must control yourself while I'm away.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I don't think we need the writer any longer.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: He's necessary. They're all necessary, do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I don't think the ship is necessary.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: The ship? What are you talking about? There are a dozen scenes on the ship.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: But I won't sail.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me this before?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: How else is the vampire suppose to get to Bremen?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Oh all right. I'll think of something. Just don't hurt my people.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Or else what?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Don't think I can't harm you.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Tell me how you would harm me. When even I am not certain how I could harm myself.  58.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I can harm you by not giving you what you want. (off Schreck's reaction) Yes, forget again who's in charge here at your own risk. Now abide by our contract--and I will, too. MURNAU storms out. SCHRECK watches him go. Then he pulls the locket he stole: the one with GRETA's picture in it.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: But thy strong Hours indignant work'd their wills, And beat me down and marr'd and wasted me, And tho' they could not end me, left me maim'd To dwell in presence of immortal youth, Immortal age beside immortal youth, And all I was in ashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRETA, as Ellen, wakes from a nightmare. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GALEEN, GRAU, PAUL, and a few peasants stand watching as wagon containing MULLER's coffin drives away. Enter ELKE MARIA, in bathing suits and sunglasses, carrying a picnic basket. They're followed by GUSTAV, similarly attired.

dialogues.speaker: ELKE
dialogues.text: We're going to the river. GUSTAV lopes over to the others.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: What are you going to do today?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: I thought I might get drunk. GRAU produces a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: What's that? The local schnapps? It's not bad, actually. Look, why don't you come down to the river with (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUSTAV (cont'd) us, sit upon the ground and tell sad stories about the death of kings.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Gustav...

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Sorry, look I'm upset about Wolf's death, too. But my God the place is depressing enough as it is.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: All right Gustav, go swim. (to Paul) You go, too.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Herr Grau.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: If you change your minds, you know where to find us. GUSTAV and PAUL join the girls and jog off.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: How much of that stuff do you have?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Three bottles.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: You think it might make us blind?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Hope so. Hey, how ‘bout a drive?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: (opening the car door) How 'bout Poland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GALEEN and GRAU are sprawled out drunk in one of the cour yards of Orlock's castle. Moonlight illuminates two empty bottles of schnapps at their feet. They pass the third.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Albin, what's the most wondrous thing you've ever seen?  60.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: I saw ectoplasm once.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: What's that? Ectoplasm?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: It's the mystical substance of ghosts. I saw a spiritualist pull it out of his mouth in Italy.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: What did it look like?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Seaweed.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Is that what we're suppose to look like when we die?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: I hope not. What about you? What was the most wondrous thing you ever saw?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: (conspiratorially) I saw Greta Schroeder naked.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Beats ectoplasm. Suddenly SCHRECK emerges from the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Jesus, Max, you scared me to death.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: How long have you been listening there?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: We've been searching this place all day for your coffin.
