dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Maybe this isn't his resting place.  61.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: You know, you're right. I wouldn't let cameras into my house. Didn't we have something to say to him... SCHRECK walks over to them, glares menacingly. They're to drunk to notice.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Silent fucker, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: .-.something about Herr Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Right. Max...Friedrich Wilhelm Murnau, the great white hope of the German film industry, has gone to Berlin to fetch a new photographer.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Wolf's dead.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: So you can take the funny ears off.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Albin. Please. The man's an artist.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: He's still in character. That's dedication.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Hey, ask him some vampire questions.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: All right. Count Orlock...is your name really Count Orlock?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I can't recall. SCHRECK sits next to them. They hand him the bottle, he sniffs at it, takes a sip. In the dark, only his head and hands really show.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: When did you first become a vampire?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Where were you born? Or were you born?  62.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I can't remember. He takes another drink.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: This isn't any fun.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Do you think Count Dracula forgot?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I read that book. Murnau gave it to me.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Well this is quite an opportunity. Speaking as a vampire, what is your opinion of the book's technical merits?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: It made me sad.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Because Dracula had no servants.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: I think you missed the point of that book, Orlock.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Dracula hasn't had servants in four hundred years. And then a man comes to his ancestral home and he must convince him that he's still...that he's like the man. He has to feed him, when he himself hasn't eaten food in centuries. Can he even remember how to buy bread? How to select cheese and wine?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Speaking of which... SCHRECK takes a pull, passes the bottle...

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: And then he has to remember the rest of it: how to prepare a meal, how to (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCHRECK (cont'd) make a bed. He remembers his past glory--his armies, his retainers--and what he is reduced to. The loneliest moment in the book is when the man accidentally sees Dracula setting his table. «--gets the bottle back, drinks. He's starting to sway.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: If you're so lonely why don't you...make more vampires?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Iocan't. I'm too old. Although I seem to recall that I was never able to.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: How did you become a vampire?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: It was a woman.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Now we're getting somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: What woman?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: My wife. My first and only wife.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: She was a vampire?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I don't know. She was my child bride. She went into labor with our first child. I was not permitted to see her in this condition. Perhaps she died-- I know the baby did. But she returned to me that night. And after that I only saw her at night. And then I grew ill and became after many, many years what I am now. He starts to break down. Drinks more. A bat flutters by. SCHRECK grabs it, bites into it. GALEEN and GRAU watch in astonishment, too drunk to realize the danger they're in.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Schreck, the German theater needs you.  64. SCHRECK finishes with the bat: there's blood on his chin he looks even sadder than before.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: We were together in the night and then she left me. At first I hada painting of her on wood. And then I had a relief of her in marble. And then I had a picture of her in my mind. And now I no longer even have that. What was I saying?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Easy with the bottle there, old boy.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: This is the schnapps they make in these parts. I haven't tasted it in... He drops the bottle, bolts to his feet. Then he looks at two men and lurches away. GALEEN retrieves the bottle, wi off its mouth in disgust. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU, half-dressed, talks on the phone at the same time excitedly arranges his office as a screening room: arrang chairs, setting up a screen, etc.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (into the phone) I don't care what they're paying you, Greta, we have a contract. Greta...Greta...look. What is it you really want? He steps behind his desk, begins loading film onto a movi projector sitting there. Too distracted to notice that someone's listening to him from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: It's to live forever, isn't it? To be beautiful and brilliant until the end of time? Well the stage can't do that for you. Because in the course of a few generations there won't be a living soul to remember what you did on it. Only film can make you immortal, Greta. Do you understand? Only I can make you immortal. Greta...Greta... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the 65. MURNAU (CONT.) (cont'd) (at wits' end) «+eoh, all right I'll match their pay. receiver onto its cradle, looks up to see MICHELINE--wearing a diaphanous gown, carrying a bottle o champagne--framed in the archway leading to the hall. The effect is not unlike that of Orlock when first we saw him

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Hold it! What a shot! He makes a little finger viewfinder. She walks up to him, kisses him. They wrestle She rolls on He pulls her down on top of him with a bang.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor, can I make it better?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Yes, you can kiss my bruises. Better still, beat me black and blue and then kiss them.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: No, you hit me first.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: No, you hit me. around on the floor, end up in a long embrace. top of him and grabs him by the throat.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Enough of this mystery. Why are you back so soon? And don't tell me it's just to placate Greta Schroeder.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You're hurting me...

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: You're checking up on my faithfulness, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I came back to see you. I couldn't stand to be away. She rolls off him laughing. Pours a glass of champagne fo herself (MURNAU doesn't drink).

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: And I have a surprise for you.  66.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: I hate surprises. What is it? MURNAU climbs to his feet, fumbles with the projector.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: My movie. He finishes with the projector, kneels in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Do you remember that book you gave me?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: What book?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Dracula.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: (suspicious) Yes...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I've filmed it. Or I'd begun to...until Wolf died.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Then it's true what they're saying in the papers...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You can't know what a nightmare it's been. Between the financiers and the crew and...the rest of it. But I've gone too far to stop now. I'm here to find another photographer. Then I go back to the Carpathians... (returning to the projector) +--and then from there to Wismar on the Baltic. And finally to Helgoland in the North Sea. And then, at last, I'll come back to you.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: «--you've filmed Dracula. He turns on the movie (the scene where Orlock menaces Hut outside his room in the castle). MURNAU watches from besi the projector. MICHELINE sits quickly, faces the screen.  67.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: This is the vampire, the first time we see him as he is: not trying to act human.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: What have you done, Friedrich? He's so ugly.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: He's perfect. MURNAU watches for a moment, when suddenly the phone ring Deflated (evidently it's GRETA again), he hurries out to answer it elsewhere. While we stay with...

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: The dirge begins again, the scene projected on the screen to more images of the sun setting. And we look at her fac mesmerized by the sight of the sun. Like SCHRECK's. The music builds as we begin a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men retrieve their equipment, load it into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the projector runs, MARIA and ELKE finish packing t things. Watching them from the shadows is SCHRECK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAU casts his fortune in the tarot cards, while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+»»MARIA and GUSTAV skinny-dip in the moonlight, ELKE wa them from the shore. Until a shadow appears behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above: we glide silently over the forest, a thread o phosphorescent mist woven through the trees. Eventually pinpricks of light appear in the breaks in the canopy and becomes evident that a... From ground level: mob of peasants--carrying torches, lea dogs--is moving across the forest floor. Following them i the remaining film company car. Suddenly the forest is illuminated from above. There's a chopping sound, the car pulls to a stop as a...

dialogues.speaker: FOKKER
dialogues.text: a WWI tri-plane swoops low above them. It circles and lan in a clearing hemmed-in by sheer cliffs, the plane cuts i engines, the pilot climbs out. MURNAU.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: (rushing over to him) Herr Doctor!

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Albin, what's happening here?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor, thank God! Elke's dead.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Elke? What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: You've returned just in time. They've caught the vampire.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: What!?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Do you think it could be the one that killed Wolf, too?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Henrik, calm down. Albin?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Apparently someone--or something-- stole a baby from one of the locals. The mother saw it and set the dogs on (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAU (cont'd) him. As far as reality goes, you can't get much better than this. GRAU gestures to where the dogs are baying and we see:

dialogues.speaker: RUINS
dialogues.text: we're not sure we've seen before: obscured by vines, carved into the living rock. The mob stops in front of it, kneels as a priest climbs its stairs and solemnly begins praying. Suddenly, from inside, there's a blood-freezing scream.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: We've got to get in there.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? I'm not going in there. And that's when we notice the figure (WAGNER) in the Fokk passenger seat. He climbs into the pilot seat, cocks the plane's machine guns. And fires...

dialogues.speaker: RUINS
dialogues.text: «».vicocheting bullets off the fagade in a shower of dust Chasing away the priest. Scattering the peasants. Silence A dog howls, there's another scram from inside. The dumbfounded crew watch as the figure leaps out of the plane, peels off his goggles: he's in his early 30s, tall blonde, wearing military uniform complete with sidearm.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: I'll go in there.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Meet our new photographer. Fritz Arno Wagner.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: What in hell was that all about?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Just a demonstration. I get impatient waiting for the mumbo jumbo to end, if you know what I mean. Now, why don't you hold onto this and I'll get my camera.  70. He reaches into the plane, pulls out a large metal canist stenciled "Giftgas."

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: It's from the war. Mustard gas. WAGNER retrieves his camera/tripod, hoists it onto his shoulder, climbs down from the plane, and then heads in t direction of the ruins...

dialogues.speaker: GRAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (to Murnau) I like this guy. -.--with the rest of the men in tow. The peasants clear a for them at the entrance to the ruins. WAGNER sets up his camera, takes the canister from GALEEN, twists something, tosses it inside. Begins filming. An instant later there's a flash and an explosion. Parts the fagade clatter to the earth, smoke and bats belch out entrance, the mob shrieks and runs away.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: You ass! There's a baby in there.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: (still filming) Nothing to fear.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: It's just a harmless smoke bomb. After a few moments, the smoke clears and the crew--along a few local men--go inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part cave, part ruins: stalactites drip from the ceiling, brick archways lead into dark recesses. The men move gingerly, squinting through the smoke, stepping over the stunned bats squeaking on the ground. Suddenly, the dogs snarl... ---and a figure--coughing, bellowing--staggers from the shadows. MURNAU takes a step toward him, but before he reaches him WAGNER manages to draw his gun. Shoots the figure, winging him in the shoulder. The figure chokes, d into the smoke still clinging to the ground.  71.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: I thought you needed a wooden stake to do that. MURNAU rushes to the body, turns it over. CLOSE ON: an ashen-faced man with jagged teeth and a shav head. But it isn't SCHRECK--although the man seems to hav disfigured himself in order to resemble him.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: stands, breathes a private sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Well, Henrik. Here's your lunatic who thinks he's a vampire. Just then a baby cries, the dogs bark. A few of the men r into one of the dark recesses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and emerge carrying the (healthy) baby and the (wounde vampire. PAUL walks up to MURNAU et al.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: They're saying it was the son of a widow who recently died. Nota vampire at all. Just some local driven crazy by grief or something. At that, an old peasant women walks up to MURNAU. For a moment we think she's about to offer congratulations. But instead she lets rip a torrent of unintelligible abuse th ends with her spitting on the ground. She's followed by a few others who cross themselves at th sight of WAGNER (and especially his camera) before headin off. The crew watches, then gathers by the plane.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Damn, end of reel. You know, I could film this in slow motion and it would be incredibly moving.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: What's that? Slow motion?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: I run the film through the camera too fast. That way, when it's projected (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAGNER (cont'd) at normal speed, things appear to be moving unnaturally slow. It gives everything a kind of resonance.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Fritz is a genius at the mechanics of trick photography. It's too bad he won't have a chance to demonstrate his more esoteric skills in this production.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: As you say, Herr Doctor. WAGNER smiles, throws GRAU a "wait and see" look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutter descends to Orlock's crypt, discovers his coffin. (Recreated from Nosferatu.) CLOSE ON: the coffin lid. Through its cracks, Hutter sees the sleeping vampire... (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: HUTTER
dialogues.text: «..throws back the lid, stumbles back to the staircase, a paralyzed with fear--pulls himself out of the crypt. )Recreated from Nosferatu.) GRAU (0.S. You know, I've never understood this part of the book. Sarah Bernhardt slept in a coffin and no one ever accused her of being a vampire.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And--end. Very good, Gustav. Extra- ordinary show of discipline in the face of ridicule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men strip off their goggles. MARIA and PAUL turn off lights, begin coiling cables, etc.  73.

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: (returning) God, I'm exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Fritz, what's left? It's almost four.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: (still in the coffin) Four?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Are the coffins ready?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: They're already in the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Good. Everybody hurry please. Everyone exits...except MURNAU who, contemplating his gog bridles under WAGNER's usurpation of his control. A moment later, GUSTAV returns to retrieve a lost pair of gloves. Looks at MURNAU for a moment...

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: What do you expect, Herr Doctor? When things go wrong people prefer generals to oracles. ...then he picks up an oil lantern, leads MURNAU out. As light fades out on the stairs, SCHRECK climbs out of the coffin, follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU catches up with the others.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor, I've got a great idea for the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Please, Fritz, just film it the way I want.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: What is it Fritz?  74.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Let's not even discuss it.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: (to Murnau) I thought you were open to the unexpected. (to Grau) All right, in this scene the vampire is loading his coffins onto a cart in order to ship himself to Germany, right? What if I run the film through the camera a few frames per second too slow?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Then, when the film is projected at the normal speed, Count Orlock appears to be moving incredibly fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They emerge in an outer courtyard opening onto the woods.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: And then listen to this: we finish the scene with stop-motion animation. Orlock climbs into an open coffin, the coffin lid scrambles up all by it- self...and closes on top of him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Then the driverless wagon pulls away as if by occult intervention. It's perfect. Waiting for them is a horsecart and a pile of plain woode coffins. PAUL adjusts a light from a window above, SCHREC examines the coffins.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Fritz, you got your way with the carriage, wasn't that enough?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: That wasn't my way, Herr Doctor. That was in the script, right Henrik?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: The script calls for the vampire's carriage, the one carrying Hutter to (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GALEEN (cont'd) the castle, to pass through a white forest at night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In negative: Orlock's carriage drives through the forest. (Actual footage from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That's just poetry. The reality of the page.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: It's a heightened reality.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: It's merely a display of technical virtuosity. An obvious falsehood. An illusion.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor, you're the Renaissance man, not me. Haven't you read Plato? The illusion is the shadow on the wall. The reality is the thing which casts the shadow in the first place: in this instance, a piece of celluloid a few millimeters in width. Anything can happen on the celluloid, anything can be engineered there. Because that's the only reality.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I'm tired of your sophisms. It will be light shortly. Let's get on with it.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (resigned) Let's see it. WAGNER runs into the castle. A few seconds later we see h goggled face leaning out of the window with the camera.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Let's try to do this one in one take, please. Take your place, Max...right there. Good. Ready? Lights, (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAGNER (cont'd) camera...and--action. Whoops, sorry. That's your line, Herr Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above, in fast-motion: Orlock begins loading his cof into the cart. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All right, Count Orlock. These are the coffins which contain the soil in which you were interred. They possess all your power and they are the only things that you will take with you from your homeland. All right, Fritz?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fine. He loads the last coffin onto the cart, climbs into it, t lid scrambles up and seals him in. The cart drives away.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And--end.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: The cart remains where it was--loaded with coffins, SCHRE recumbent in the last one, its lid on the ground. WAGNER hurries out of the castle, yanks off his goggles.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Great. Paul, reset the camera for the animation sequence. Albin, bring a piece of chalk and mark the shot. Gustav, make yourself useful and hold the reins of this horse. Everyone jumps to his orders. The significance of this do not escape MURNAU who stands off to one side watching.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Come on, Henrik, don't look so glum. One last shot and we'll all take a little cruise to Wismar. As he bustles with authority, we look up to see a remarka thing: looming over the side of the ruined castle are the prow and masts of a ship being constructed on the site.  77. Then the opening dirge, this time sung by a woman, begins build and we begin another...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cutting between the scenes in Nosferatu where the vampire sails to Germany and scenes of the crew--on the landlocked ship--filming those same scenes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "Demeter," a two-masted ship sails the ocean. (Actual footage from Nosferatu. )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The captain and mate throw a linen-wrapped corpse overboa (Actual footage from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hold containing Orlock's coffins. The mate picks up a axe and smashes one of them open. Rats swarm out. (Actual footage from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: COFFIN
dialogues.text: From the mate's P.O.V.: Orlock rises magically from his box. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: crouched behind SCHRECK, pushing him up. We pull back to see WAGNER filming the scene while MURNAU watches from the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the crew sets up equipment, MURNAU and WAGNER angri trade words.  78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In stop-motion: the tarp covering the entrance to the hol scrambles back, the door opens, and Orlock peeks out. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From below: Orlock menaces on the deck while the masts/li tower above him. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew finishes shooting and exits into the ruins--leav PAUL, alone, to pack up the equipment. As he turns off th lights, a shadow angles down across the sails--which turn to be SCHRECK, creeping up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ghostly ship sails into Bremen with no one at the hel (Actual footage from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rats swarm out of the hold, and scurry into the streets. (Actual footage from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above: a procession of pall bearers carries coffins through the Medieval street. (Actual footage from Nosferatu.) The dirge ends along with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From below: we look up to see WAGNER filming the processi GRAU, MURNAU, and GALEEN stand beside him. They all look exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Here's the real heightened reality, Fritz. No tricks. Nothing engineered in the camera.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: (real admiration) You'll get no argument from me, Herr Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: It's perfect, Friedrich.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: What do you think, Henrik? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: (through a megaphone) And--end! (to Grau) I have to get the plane fueled for the flight to Helgoland tonight. Take care of things here for me. MURNAU exits. The others pack up the equipment, exit, and catch up with them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -.-as they emerge on the street. Then, as GRAU directs th collection of the last pallbearer's prop coffin...

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Listen, Albin, what are you doing tonight? You, too, Fritz.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Well if I'm not mistaken, there's one last scene to be shot here. A night scene where the vampire carries his coffin to his new home.  80.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: And then afterward? Will you both be back in the hotel?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, no. I've made an appointment to see a rather renown spiritualist living here in Wismar. An ectoplasmist. Why?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: (whispers) I've found out where Schreck sleeps. Where the vampire sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Oh, please, Henrik. Don't start this again. What's the matter with you? GRAU signs off on the props, turns, heads off. We follow men through the winding Medieval streets.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: What's the matter with me? For the love of God, Albin. People are dead.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: That's all over.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Over? Where's Paul? What happened to him then?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe he just got fed up and left.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Doesn't anybody care anymore? I know I can't expect anything from Murnau, but...look, just give me an hour. Tonight, after your spiritualist.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Oh, for chrissakes, Henrik, do you know what kind of day we're going to have tomorrow? It's a six hour drive to Cuxhaven before we even get on the boat. I don't know how long it takes to sail to the damn island.  81.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Where we'll be cut off. Secluded. I've got to show you this before we find ourselves sequestered with him. They stop in front of the door to their hotel (rustic, ga and we follow them inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where they discover, talking with GUSTAV: GRETA. She wear fur coat and is surrounded by yapping little dogs.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Greta! Kisses all around.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Why can't Herr Doctor film in a studio like everybody else? Wismar. Is there anything here that even vaguely resembles a cabaret?

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: If you think this is bad, wait till we get to Helgoland.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: I'm suffering for my art, believe me. (spots Galeen) Henrik, you look terrible.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Greta, you should leave here right away.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: I knew it. Melodrama. What's going on here, anyway? Herr Doctor tells me to lock my door at night, Gustav says everybody's dropping dead, and you can imagine what they're saying in Berlin. (spotting Wagner) Hello. You look very familiar.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: You remember me, don't you Greta? From Morocco.  82.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember you. You brought me treats. What was your name again? Fritzie?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: That's right. Fritzie

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Fritzie? GRETA takes WAGNER by the arm, leads him upstairs...

dialogues.speaker: GUSTAV
dialogues.text: Has anybody seen Maria? .-.--followed by GUSTAV, then GRAU.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: (shouting) Albin, will you come tonight?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: (tired of arguing) Yes, yes. Alright, Henrik. GALEEN, alone, steps to the window. Watches the sun set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow a figure down the crooked streets and into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dirt floor, books, a coffin with a candle burning on to it. SCHRECK sits beside it reading. Enter...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: We leave tonight after you finish your last scene here. We're flying north, but west so there should be no problem.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: (not looking up) She's here, isn't she? The glorious child...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: No.  MURNAU looks 83.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I want to see her now.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: No. I won't have you interfering with her like you did poor Wolf.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: And I won't act again for you until you bring her to me.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Don't you see you're ruining everything for both of us? As it is everyone is about to bolt. As far as they're concerned, I'm just like you. I'm nosferatu.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: You are nosferatu. at him, shocked. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Greta is in your last scene. That's when you can have her.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: After my death scene...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Don't expect realism there, Murnau.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: (hisses) Don't cheat me, mortal. I'll take her anytime I please...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Keep away from her. Keep away from my people. Leave my movie alone.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: This is hardly your movie anymore.  84. MURNAU grabs SCHRECK by the throat, pins him to the groun At first we think he's strangling him, but then we realiz that SCHRECK's sibilant wheezing is actually laughter. Suddenly his features go blank. He grabs MURNAU, lifts hi off the ground, and throws him crashing into the wall. He scrambles to his feet...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Wait until Helgoland. We'll make an end of it there. ...flees. SCHRECK remains behind, chuckles quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GALEEN waits impatiently beneath a sign painted with occu symbols. Through the window we can see GRAU and WAGNER watching an old man yank dough-like ectoplasm from his mo

dialogues.speaker: CLOCK
dialogues.text: Close on: a mechanical clock as it prepares to strike midnight. The gears mesh, a door opens, and a bronze devi races out pursued by a bronze knight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the clock chimes 0.S., GRAU and WAGNER emerge from the building and silently follow GALEEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men, carrying lanterns, gingerly enter the cell see the coffin. WAGNER creeps up to it, throws open the l It's empty. There's a general sigh of relief, nervous laughter. WAGNER closes it, sits, lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: How did you find this place?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: I followed Murnau here.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Oh, Henrik. You're in the wrong part of the building. There's probably a sadistic brothel upstairs.  85.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor certainly has a talent for finding awful places.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: The world is full of awful places.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: I don't understand you, Henrik. So what if Schreck sleeps here? I thought he had this...character thing. GALEEN scoops up some dirt from beside the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: This is the dirt in which he was interred. This is his original coffin. He needs these things in order to survive.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Are you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Just hear me out. As he continues 0.8., we follow--from a distance--the sub of his monologue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «.-creeping through the twisting, deserted streets of Wis Possibly heading back to the cellar where, right now, GAL holds court.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (continued) Schreck is not an actor carried away by his role. He's not even an actor. He's a vampire, a real vampire. As SCHRECK vanishes down one of the streets, we return to

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Henrik, I'm a well-known adept of the occult sciences. Don't you think if he were really a vampire I would know about it?  86.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Anyway, there are no vampires.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: He ate a bat.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: He was drunk. I was drunk. You were drunk for chrissakes.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Don't you understand? Friedrich would go to any lengths to render a movie authentically. For the Carpathians, he used the Carpathians. For peasants he used peasants. For a ruined castle he used a ruined castle. Fora vampire...he used a vampire. There is nothing he wouldn't do. Nothing. They look at him. Then WAGNER yawns, looks at his watch..

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: And I thought I might get a few hours extra sleep when Murnau canceled the shoot for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Henrik. I can see how this disturbs you. And I understand. I miss Wolf just as much as...

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: You don't understand anything. -.-and heads up the stairs followed by GRAU.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: (calling after them) Who else has to die in order to convince you? We remain behind with GALEEN for a beat, then follow him upstairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «--and outside. He hurries away. Just as SCHRECK's shadow angles in behind him. And follows him to the...  87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where GALEEN rings for the night attendant. After a tense moment, the door opens, GALEEN goes inside, the attendant shuts it behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. A door opens and MARIA--nightgown, candle--emerges She shuts her door, tiptoes to another, knocks softly.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Gustav? The door opens a crack. GUSTAV peeks out. Smiles, opens t door for her, and then shuts it again. We continue down t hall, make a sharp turn toward the steps, and discover... SCHRECK: staggering up the stairs to the landing. He look at the rows of doors, and then slowly tries them--one aft another--finding them all locked. Until, by the time he reaches the end, he's crawling like an addict in withdraw Finally, he comes to the last door, reaches up for the kn bears down on it. It twists to pieces in his hand. And th door opens. Inside we see the sleeping figure of GALEEN. SCHRECK crawls in, the door silently closes behind him. We pull away from GALEEN's room, back in the direction of stairs. And that's when we hear the scream. But it isn't GALEEN. GRAU and WAGNER emerge from their respective room rush down the hall, batter down the door. Revealing...

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: naked in bed, laughing obscenely. She hisses at them, something clinks onto the floor. GRAU holds up a candle, lifts the object: a steel hypodermic.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: (covering Greta) Morphine.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Morphine? Photography and pharmaceuticals by Fritzie?  88.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor knows all about it.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor is always one step ahead of us, isn't he? God, for I moment there, I was afraid she...

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: She's all right. Get some sleep. We have a long trip tomorrow. WAGNER takes the needle from GRAU, pockets it. They exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlock, lugging his coffin under one arm, crosses the squ in front of an enormous gabled building. (Recreated from Nosferatu.) But just as he reaches the left foreground, he does somet odd: he looks up at us, at the camera. And that's when we realize we're shooting-day-for-night. With MURNAU himself the make-up of his vampire.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: And--end! The iris twists to black, there's the sound of an airplan engine O.S., and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-MURNAU's tri-plane taxis to the edge of the field and ascends into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAU casts the tarot on an upended suitcase while GRETA-- glasses, fur coat, surrounded by luggage and lap dogs--lo on her steamer trunk. GALEEN, heavily bundled, sits by himself staring at nothi

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Henrik, come here. I'll cast your fortune. Nothing.  89.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you? You're acting just like... (to himself) «--Wolf. The hotel door opens, WAGNER steps out.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Well, he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Gustav. Maria, too. WAGNER hands GRAU a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: They've run off together.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: The porter gave me that. They hired a car and drove back to Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Typical.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Can we proceed without him?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: We'll have to, won't we?

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: If we need Gustav for anything else I'm sure we can always shanghai him in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor's going to throw a fit.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: He should have known. Gustav's a flake, everyone in the Reinhardt company knew that. Let me tell you something: when I was married to him...

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: You were married to Reinhardt?  90.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: No, Fritzie. To Gustav.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: You were married to Gustav? When?

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: We were divorced last year.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Did Murnau know this?

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Of course. He said something about wanting to cast man and wife as man and wife. Of course, I've already married again, but... GALEEN looks meaningfully at GRAU. GRAU turns back to his

dialogues.speaker: TAROT CARDS
dialogues.text: the fool, death, the ten of swords--just as he had cast o train en route to Czechoslovakia. O.S. we hear the dirge, followed this time by the sounds shore birds, waves lapping against a beach. Then, off the last of the three cards, we dissolve to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRETA, as Ellen, sits amid crosses and scrub grass lookin at the sea. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I wish the fog was a little thicker. Pop one of those smoke bombs, will you Fritz?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hardly a realistic effect, Herr Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same scene, not recreated. We pull back to see MURNAU, GALEEN, and WAGNER standing by the camera. While the latt busies himself with a smoke bomb...  91.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: But I suppose after filming you, day- for-night, dressed as the vampire-- anything is possible. ..-MURNAU throws him a look, addresses himself to GRETA.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Ellen, just keep thinking of your husband, possibly dead, far away. (to Wagner) All right--camera, action. Keep filming, Fritz. Ellen, wait for the fog. WAGNER begins cranking the camera. Enter GRAU.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Well, I think I found our studio. A fortified bunker, of all things. Part of our coastal defenses during the last war.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Good. How long will it take to build the set?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: It shouldn't take more than a day or two.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: It bloody well better not.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Keep looking out to sea, Ellen. Think of your nightmares. Your premonitions. (to Grau) All right, Albin, you and Fritz and Henrik, if he's up to it, get to work right away. There's Greta's crowded schedule to consider... She waves. MURNAU rolls his eyes, puts on his goggles...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: «-eand we only a week until the boat from Cuxhaven returns. +..-turns back to the scene.  92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the P.O.V. of the gallery: it's a dusty, subterranea building with shadowy recesses, concrete pilasters, grate niches, and an elevated gallery. Of note is the principal entrance: a steel door on a system of weights and pulleys Enter from one of the recesses: GRAU carrying a roll of blueprints. He's followed by WAGNER carrying the machine from the plane and his camera/tripod.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Can we get any natural light in here? GRAU walks over to a hand-operated locking device. Releas it. A chain plays out, the counterbalances slide to the ground, and the door rolls into the ceiling with a crash- opening onto an incline (evidently for loading purposes). O.S. we hear wind, the sound of the surf. A column of lat afternoon light angles in.

dialogues.speaker: FOKKER
dialogues.text: MURNAU's tri-plane sits on a barren, wind-blown hill abov little town--thatch-roofed huts, a few brick buildings--t constitutes civilization on the otherwise barren island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU enters, examines the half-built set for Ellen's be room--a stage wall with a window, a chair, a table, a bed a mirror beside it--and then walks over to the door relea Opens it. The door rolls up with a bang...

dialogues.speaker: GALLERY
dialogues.text: .«.-waking GRAU and WAGNER who are napping amid a jumble of equipment and empty schnapps bottles. GRAU roots around for a full bottle, WAGNER begins to roll a cigarette. From the open door we hear the sound of the surf, the wind blowing.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: (peering down) What's Friedrich doing down there?  93.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Who can fathom the ways of genius? Hey, what's that?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Hashish. He lights up, passes it to GRAU. Downstairs...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: stands looking out the door, listening to the wind and the waves. When suddenly a figure emerges from the fog- shrouded night. MURNAU's face lights up with surprise. As MICHELINE emerges from the darkness. The lights in the bunker flicker imperceptibly, she steps up to the amazed MURNAU, puts her arms around his neck, kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU AND WAGNER
dialogues.text: Watch in utter astonishment as...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: shuts the door again (reversed, the door release cranks t chain through the mechanism and locks it off), and then l himself be led, by MICHELINE, to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: How...

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Shhh. Don't say anything... She pushes him down on it and climbs on top of him. They begin tearing off each other's clothes. While...

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: picks up his camera, winds it up.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: (whispering) Hand me that blanket. GRAU hands it to him...

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: (whispering) What are you doing?  94.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Capturing reality. I think Herr Doctor would approve.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: That's disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Think of the possibilities. It could be the movie of the future. ..-WAGNER takes it, wraps the camera in it (to muffle its noise). Then he grabs his goggles, begins filming:

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU AND MICHELINE
dialogues.text: We watch them for a moment, then we begin pulling back. O to discover SCHRECK, standing in the shadows beside a mov projector. Watching them.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, there's Max. As SCHRECK watches, MICHELINE pulls off her slip and clim top of MURNAU--facing away from him. They fuck for a long while, then she stops a little. Begins to pull away.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: (breathlessly) What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Stay. There's nothing here for which to leave me... MURNAU grabs her breasts from behind, pulls her back to h She turns around, mounts him again, throws her head back orgasm. Revealing her features to:

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: who recoils: stumbling back, knocking into the projector, causing its carbon arc to ignite, its gears to turn, and scenes from Nosferatu (Orlock leering at Ellen) to be projected on the stage wall.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU AND MICHELINE
dialogues.text: begin scrambling for their clothes.  95.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: You!

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Max, go the fuck away! But MURNAU isn't the one he's interested in. It's...

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Look at me! Look at me!

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: who looks at him with an expression of pure ancient loath

dialogues.speaker: GRAU AND WAGNER
dialogues.text: watch thunderstruck, while...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: horrified--realizing--scuttles away from her off the bed. MICHELINE watches MURNAU, calmly pulls her cape around herself, raises herself to her full height, and:

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: h (imperiously, to Schreck) You thing!

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: How beautiful you've remained! Thou wilt renew thy beauty morn by morn, I earth in earth forget these empty courts.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: After all these years. Look what's happened.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: It happens to them all. You've aged.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Aged? I am time itself.  96.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: (sneers) And also, evidently, a movie actor.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I did it for you. I've begun losing my sight, my legs. I can barely travel past the borders of my land. So when Murnau asked me to act in his movie, I knew you would see it one day...even if it took centuries. And then you would come to me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Why? What would you have me do?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I wither slowly in thine arms, Here at the quiet limit of the world.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: You've lost your mind, old man...

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Come back to me. Stay with me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: (laughs) Stay with you!? You're an insect!

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Don't you recognize me?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I was your husband once. Your first husband.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: That may be. But I certainly don't know you now. Do you think I feel responsible for you? I feel nothing for you...or any of the others. All men are just time passing by for me. (to Murnau, tenderly) Herr Doctor...

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Stay away from her, Murnau.  97.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: (turning on him, hissing) Why are you still alive? Why haven't you had the decency to die?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: (to Murnau) She'll make of you what she made of me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: (venomously) Don't listen to him, Friedrich. He's a non-being. Someone I fucked a million lovers ago. SCHRECK attacks her. They fall against the stage wall whi pitches over so that the projected film now covers the en back wall of the bunker. She climbs to her feet, easily shoves SCHRECK away. He hobbles back, takes one last look at her. At MURNAU. Exit into the shadowy recesses of the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: (hurrying to Murnau) Oh, Friedrich. Can't you see that I love you? Isn't that what you wanted to hear? I came here to warn you. You, not him. Don't listen to the lies of the Assyrian.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Assyrian?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: He knows nothing. He's a jilted lover. You've known jilted lovers. They're all repulsive. He tricked you into contacting me.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: But you gave me that book.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: I didn't know you had stumbled upon one of them. I thought you might make a romantic Dracula...the way I've always dreamed of him. As MURNAU cringes away from her, we CLOSE ON:  98.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR RELEASE
dialogues.text: as SCHRECK's hand grabs the handle, throws the release. T chain snakes its way through the gears...

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: ...throwing the pulleys into play. While...

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: opens her arms to MURNAU.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Don't touch me!

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Friedrich. Please. I swear to you he's lying. There are no others like him. I'll leave you when we tire of each other, but I won't leave you as he. You have nothing to fear. She takes a step toward him, as the...

dialogues.speaker: WEIGHTS
dialogues.text: slide toward the floor. While...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: terrified, crawls back onto the bed. She looks at him, enraged, staggers into the empty space behind the set so the movie is projected onto her body.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: (screaming) Don't look at me like that! Does it really make so much difference!? No! Don't! Suddenly the film catches: bubbles, burns, breaks. Only t harsh white light is on her now. The sound of the project grows deafening as the...  99.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: Of course you'll die. Every man dies. Now come here to me. Don't force me to force you. Let us end this farce. This absurd scene from an absurd film.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIN
dialogues.text: plays cut as far as it can go. There's a sharp crack, a creaking O.S. and the...

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: crashes into the ceiling with an immense, echoing din. Th light of dawn barrels in on...

dialogues.speaker: MICHELINE
dialogues.text: who looks at the light. Then looks at MURNAU. Her face is over-exposed, washed-out: the bones show beneath her translucent skin. She screams in pain, and...

dialogues.speaker: THE GALLERY
dialogues.text: .-.something happens to her we've never seen before: she bubbles away into nothing. Not in a mess of viscera. But like movie film caught in the gate and burned to light. The dirge--rendered slowly, note by note on a piano--begi MURNAU looks up to see GRAU and WAGNER watching him. Exit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scene of the previous day's shoot is trashed.

dialogues.speaker: FOKKER
dialogues.text: as is the tri-plane which sits in the early morning fog w the fabric hanging in ribbons from its wooden skeleton. T music ends simultaneously with the sound 0.S. of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...GRAU and WAGNER pounding on MURNAU's door.  100.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: (speech somewhat slurred) Leave me the fuck alone! As the pounding continues 0.S. we see: INT. HELGOLAND INN -- GRETA'S ROOM — DAY GRETA--drugged, smiling incoherently--lies in bed touchin herself sensuously. And:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GALEEN--very pale, clutching a cross--cowering weakly in

dialogues.speaker: GRAU AND WAGNER
dialogues.text: The door opens, MURNAU peers fearfully out. He looks clos insanity: he's shaking, there are dark circles under his eyes. GRAU and WAGNER enter, shut the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is trashed and MURNAU has scribbled crosses on t walls, the door, etc. He slumps down in bed. WAGNER picks an empty vial on the bedside table, sniffs it.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Laudanum.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (druggy) There is no Max Schreck. They sit down on the bed with MURNAU who tells his story calmly, indifferently--as if he were speaking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Who is he then?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Where did you find him?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: In a book. When I was a student. It told the story of a legendary line of (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU (cont'd) kings, rumored to be vampires, living in Slovakia for eleven hundred years. I had forgotten all about it until she gave me the other book. Dracula. TI found him when I went to scout locations. A vampire. Living in an old monastery.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: What was your bargain with him?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: He would play the part of an actor playing the part of a vampire.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: And what did you offer him?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (locking up at them) Greta.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: How could you, Friedrich?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (nodding off) I did it for science. Don't you see? I didn't want the usual melodrama. I wanted to capture him for posterity...

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: He's fading...

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Go to sleep, Friedrich. MURNAU climbs under the blankets...

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: He'll be out again tonight. The call is for two. ---and his bloodshot eyes slowly close. After a moment we hear, 0.S., the door shut as GRAU and WAGNER exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the gallery: GRAU puts the finishing touches on the (newly-restored) bedroom set. Enter WAGNER.  102.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Think it's worth searching the island again?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: (pulling up a seat) No. He could be under the sea for all we know. The only thing we can be sure of is he'll come out at night and kill us all...slowly or quickly depending on his appetite.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: What about his bargain with Murnau?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: His vampire bride is dead. That's the only thing that mattered to him. He'll kill us, then he'll kill everyone else on this island, and then he'll stowaway on the boat back to Germany. Beat. They let this sink in.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: You know, I've been thinking. If we're going to die anyway, we might as well finish the movie. Asa testament.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: We can put the reels in beer kegs lined with pitch. Set them afloat before he can get to them--that is if he agrees to let us film him for the last shot.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: He might do it just to mollify Greta. How were you planning to film it?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Well I'm not sure anymore. The script calls for Ellen to lure the vampire to her bedroom and then kill him with a wooden stake. But evidently they don't die that way.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Indeed, none of my research indicated that vampires could be killed by (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAU (cont'd) sunlight. Stoker's is unaffected by it.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Still, I suppose I might be able to trick something up.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Yes... (idea!) .--but why bother with tricks--as Herr Doctor might say? They exchange looks, WAGNER catches his drift. Leans forw conspiratorially.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: We'd have to keep him on the set until after sunrise.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: He doesn't get there until two. With normal delays, Greta's moods, and everything else we could keep him there for days. Of course we'd need to know exactly when dawn is.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: There's a synagogue. They need to know when the sun rises and sets for their rites. All we have to do is to keep him from noticing the time. They look at each other, smile in satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Should we tell Murnau?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: No. It's perfect as it is. At dawn I'll shout his name, open the door...

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: And bang, I get it all on film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANG! Close on: a fire burning in one of the niches just GRAU shuts its iron grating, rubs his hands in its warmth Then we pull back and follow him to where he begins putti the finishing touches on the set.  104. In front of him, adjusting the lights, stands WAGNER. Sit off to one side is GALEEN. Standing at the door, looking into the night, is MURNAU. And--emerging from the shadows, his presence causing the firelight to flicker--we find SCHRECK. Enter GRETA in wig and make-up. MURNAU shuts the door, le her to the set, takes her coat revealing a plain nightgow as well as a pair of stylishly anachronistic high heels.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: You know I don't like these late shoots, Herr Doctor. Where is every- body? Why don't I have an assistant?

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: (going to her) Did you put this make-up on with a broom, Greta?

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Stop fussing, Albin. Can I have a cigarette? Where's my script? Henrik? What's the matter with him? Why does everybody look so depressing? (shouts) Hey, who died? At that, SCHRECK stalks over to her. He carries a canvas chair and offers it to her with exaggerated politeness.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Jesus, look at you. She sits in the chair and looks sideways at him. He stand beside her and leers.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: Herr Doctor? Herr Doctor!?

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: (still holding her coat) Yes. What is itr?

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: What is it? What's the shot? What's going on here? He puts down the coat, walks listlessly to her.  105.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: All right, Greta. In this scene, you make the ultimate sacrifice for love: you seduce the vampire in order to dispatch him, just before you die, with a wooden stake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlock's shadow creeps up the staircase outside of Ellen' bedroom. (Actual footage from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen sits up in her bed in fear. The shadow of Orlock's passes over her until it reaches her heart. Then it clinc and she grimaces in pain. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Really all you have to do is lie there in fear and Max will do the rest.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: You had me travel sixty kilometers into the middle of the cold North Sea just to do that? She gets into bed. SCHRECK takes his position between the and the mirror mounted on the wall behind him. He looks d at her, gently brushes her breast with his long nails.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: (pushing his hand away) Watch it, asshole. MURNAU puts on his lab coat and goggles. Walks over to wh GRAU and WAGNER stand behind the camera. He looks at them nudges the camera over. It shatters in an explosion of gl and uncoiling film.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Damn! Hold it! Set up the other camera, Fritz. Albin, there's another (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURNAU (cont'd) reel up in the gallery. Sorry, actors. It'll just be a moment. WAGNER and GRAU look at each other in amazement: evidentl MURNAU has a plan similar to theirs. SCHRECK, irritated, marches off the set.

dialogues.speaker: POCKETWATCH
dialogues.text: 3:45. MURNAU closes the cover and we pull back to see:

dialogues.speaker: BUNKER
dialogues.text: ..-MURNAU pocket his watch, adjust his goggles. WAGNER finishes setting a new camera on the tripod. SCHRECK, climbing the walls, storms over to them.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I'm tired of waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: All right, places. Let's have lights... SCHRECK walks over to the set and resumes his position, G adjusts the lights, slips on his goggles.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Camera... WAGNER yanks on his own goggles, and begins filming...

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: who lies, acting fearful, in bed. SCHRECK, between her an the wall, kneels and is preparing to bite her when she no the mirror behind him. And the fact that SCHRECK casts no reflection.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: And... Before MURNAU can say "action," she starts screaming.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: +--end! GRAU and MURNAU rush to her side.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: What is it?  107.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: (pointing at the mirror) He casts...he doesn't... SCHRECK glares at GRAU.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU
dialogues.text: Got a little problem here, Count Dracula.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Let me have her Murnau. Now.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Fritz? WAGNER walks over, winks at SCHRECK.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Let me take care of this.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Do it quickly. What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Barely two, two-thirty. Come on baby. Look what Fritzie has for you.

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: No, Fritz. Help me, please. WAGNER fishes in his pocket and pulls out a hypodermic ne Then he goes in search of morphine, but before he can fin MURNAU hands him a vial. WAGNER looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Great minds think alike. WAGNER prepares the shot, injects her. She relaxes, falls into a stupor. MURNAU walks over to SCHRECK who storms at edge of the set.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: For the effect of you dissolving into thin air after she's stabbed you with her stake, we need a shot of you clutching your heart. Will you do that for me? First?

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: My death scene. Very well.  108.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Good. Thank you. How is she, Fritz?

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: (walking back to his camera) Never better. GRAU, MURNAU, and WAGNER take their places by the camera. SCHRECK once again stands beside...

dialogues.speaker: GRETA
dialogues.text: whose eyes flutter in a narcotic daze. SCHRECK kneels dow beside her, runs his fingernails slowly along her legs an arms. She barely notices.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Control yourself for a moment, Count. Fritz, we'll need something from your bag of tricks. Overlap with dissolve, I think.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're the director, Herr Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Good. Camera--Action.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN AND COUNT ORLOCK
dialogues.text: Orlock kneels beside Ellen's bed and drinks her blocd. (Recreated from Nosferatu)

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You've been drinking her blood all night, Count. You can barely move, you're so intoxicated with blood and desire. But wait. What's that? It's a wooden stake. She's tricked you. She plunges it into your heart. Your head spins, you stagger to the door...but it's too late! Turn around, Schreck! Grab your heart in pain and die, you fucking bastard vampire shit, DIE!! Orlock turns, extends one arm, and dissolves into nothing

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: And--end. Got it, Fritz?  109.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Got it. You know, in a pinch you could use that to suggest the vampire dissolved in the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: I'll keep that in mind.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: That's enough, Murnau. I'1l take her now.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: (still filming) Just a moment longer, Dracula. I need a few seconds of the set without you. SCHRECK kicks over the chair, rages like a junkie denied fix. GRAU goes to GRETA, repositions her on the bed, fixe her hair, etc. WAGNER films the bare wall for a few minut

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I said that's enough.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: Just let me change the reel. He does. Begins filming again.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: Just a few more seconds, Max. SCHRECK charges over to GRETA, shoves GRAU roughly away.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Go to hell, Murnau. Action! He falls beside her, licks his chops, bites her in the ne There's a little popping noise, she winces. After a few seconds, his eyes grow heavy and he starts to nod off: th heroin is tranquilizing him as well as GRETA.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU, GALEEN, MURNAU AND WAGNER
dialogues.text: watch with disgust. MURNAU recovers, indicates the camera WAGNER begins filming.  110.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: Later. He's sleeping in a chair a distance from the set.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU AND MURNAU
dialogues.text: stand off to one side: smoking cigarettes, consulting the respective timepieces.

dialogues.speaker: WAGNER
dialogues.text: leans on his camera, smokes, looks at his wristwatch: 5:4 Then he looks at:

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK AND GRETA
dialogues.text: SCHRECK appears to be biting GRETA as before, but when we closer we see that he's actually asleep.

dialogues.speaker: GRAU AND MURNAU
dialogues.text: GRAU shows his watch to MURNAU, walks over to WAGNER. WAG begins silently cranking the camera. Then he looks over a MURNAU. And nods.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (shouts) Schreck! SCHRECK wakes. He looks at MURNAU, looks to his left. His eyes open angrily, he climbs unsteadily to his feet. And that's when we look over to see what's enraged him:

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: standing with his hand on the door release. He looks at..

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: who nods back at him.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: pulls it, the release opens, the chain plays through for feet. Until suddenly there's no more chain.

dialogues.speaker: GALEEN
dialogues.text: He cut it.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: So you would break our bargain? He staggers toward MURNAU, but he's still pretty shaky...

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: You think you know so much, Herr Doctor. But I can still...kill you... .-.and he stumbles, grabs the wall for support.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: I can break your necks and drain your blood...and...I can...you tried to trick me. He takes a deep breath, regains his composure somewhat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: It's daybreak, is it? So what? I'11 stay here and then at dusk...only I will walk out alive.

dialogues.speaker: MURNAU
dialogues.text: You forget that you don't have the coffin in which you were interred. SCHRECK smiles. Gets between MURNAU and the others, sprea his talons, and bears down on him.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: I was never interred. I told you before you know nothing of me. Nor do any of you. All I need is to sleep in darkness. Coldly thy rosy shadows bathe me, cold are all thy lights. Suddenly WAGNER grabs the machine gun and shoots several rounds into him. The bullets poke a few dusty holes out o him, but don't seem to do much else. SCHRECK flies at MURNAU, but MURNAU manages to slip away him. He grabs the gun and shoots again. This time, the  112. bullets not only pierce SCHRECK, but the door behind him. Light shoots in through the holes. SCHRECK sees it, a scream catches in his throat. And, at sight of the sun, something like ecstasy flickers across features. Resigned, in the moment he has left to live he physically throws open the heavy steel door. His body diminishes in the overexposure. And then he, lik MICHELINE before him, bubbles and vanishes. MURNAU stands watching the fluttering scraps of clothing remain. He picks up a long pole, fishes them up (along wi the remains of MICHELINE's cape which lies in a heap on t ground), and shoves them into the fire. GALEEN slams the grating shut afterward. The dirge begins Then, as we watch the fire, the film itself seems to smol until it changes into the black and white stock of the original Nosferatu. The...

dialogues.speaker: MEN
dialogues.text: stand beside GRETA. She wakes a little, evidently unharme Everyone laughs nervously. On the old-fashioned film stoc their actions seem jerky and unreal. Meanwhile the...

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA
dialogues.text: has been shattered by a bullet and exposed film is coilin and piling up on the floor. We watch this for a moment, a then we pull up until we're watching from the...

dialogues.speaker: THE GALLERY
dialogues.text: as WAGNER walks away from the others and begins extinguis the arc-lights. One at a time. Until he turns off the las one and everything... All that's left is the music and the old silent movie fil stock over which we...
